abstract.t: This document provides step-by-step worked examples of evidence collection, chain construction, and verification using the Proof of Process architecture. The examples illustrate typical authorship scenarios including a short writing session, a multi-day project, and a verification workflow. Each example includes representative data values to assist implementers in testing their systems.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The Proof of Process (PoP) specification defines the architecture and data formats for authorship attestation, but the abstract protocol description can be difficult to follow without concrete examples. This companion document walks through several representative scenarios, showing the exact sequence of operations performed by the Attester, the data structures produced, and the verification steps carried out by the Verifier.

All examples in this document use simplified values for readability. Hash values are truncated, timestamps are shown in human-readable form, and VDF outputs are represented as short hexadecimal strings. Production implementations will use full-length values as specified in the base protocol.

The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCP 14 when, and only when, they appear in all capitals, as shown here.

section.title: Example 1: Short Writing Session
section.t: Alice begins writing a 500-word blog post at 10:00 AM. Her Attester device generates a session initialization record containing a fresh VDF seed derived from hardware entropy. The session record is signed with Alice's device key and stored locally.

Over the next 25 minutes, the Attester captures evidence at 30-second intervals. Each evidence packet includes the keystroke timing deltas since the previous packet, the SHA-256 hash of the current document state, and a VDF output computed from the previous packet's VDF output concatenated with the current content hash. By 10:25 AM, the chain contains 50 evidence records.

Alice finishes the blog post and closes her editor. The Attester produces a session finalization record that includes the final document hash, the total word count (512 words), and the cumulative VDF output. The complete evidence chain is serialized in CBOR () and stored alongside the finished document.

section.title: Example 2: Multi-Day Project
section.t: Bob is writing a 10,000-word short story over five days. Each day, he opens the document and the Attester resumes the evidence chain from where it left off. The session resumption record references the last evidence packet from the previous session, ensuring chain continuity across editing sessions.

On day three, Bob takes a two-hour break in the middle of a session. The Attester detects the period of inactivity and produces an idle marker record. When Bob resumes typing, the Attester generates a resumption record that includes both a fresh VDF computation and a reference to the idle marker. This gap handling ensures that the evidence chain accurately reflects the actual timeline of creative effort.

By the end of day five, Bob's evidence chain contains 1,247 records spanning 14 hours of active writing time. The chain captures the evolution of the story from a 200-word outline to the final 10,340-word manuscript, providing a complete temporal record of the authorship process.

section.title: Example 3: Verification Workflow
section.t: Carol is a literary agent who has received Bob's manuscript along with the exported evidence chain. She submits the evidence to a Verifier service for authentication. The Verifier performs the following steps in sequence.

First, the Verifier checks that every evidence record in the chain is properly signed by Bob's device key and that the signatures form a valid COSE_Sign1 chain. Second, the Verifier recomputes each VDF output from its inputs and confirms that the chain is temporally consistent -- each VDF computation requires wall-clock time proportional to the configured difficulty parameter. Third, the Verifier analyzes the keystroke timing data using statistical methods to confirm that the typing patterns are consistent with human authorship rather than automated generation.

The Verifier produces an attestation result indicating that Bob's evidence chain is authentic with a confidence score of 0.97. Carol can present this attestation to publishers as evidence that the manuscript was genuinely authored by a human over the claimed time period.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: The examples in this document use simplified and truncated values that are not suitable for production use. Implementers MUST use full-length cryptographic values as specified in the base Proof of Process document. The simplified values are provided solely to illustrate the protocol flow.
